div.p:
Pango Efate
Aug 25th 73
My dear [Cassie]
I wonder how big
you are now. It will soon be two
years since I saw you, so you
must have grown considerable in
that time. But there is something
else that I feel more anxious to know
than your size – It was this – Are you
a better girl now than you were
two years ago? Do you love Jesus more
and do you work more for Him. Re
member you have not to come among
the heathen in order to work for Jesus
you can do this at home you can
tell other little girls to love Him,
biut more than this you can be
kind to all at home and when others
are are cross with you, love them for their
hatred. "Render not evil for evil"

This is quite a cool night. I had to go
and put a warm coat on. I suppose you
often wonder what I am doing. Well I
have a great vriety of work. I was busy
packing flour to-day. We have to [xx]
careful with all our provisions in case
they spoil. I suppose you often wonder
what kind of food we have. To-day we
had preserved beef – we get meat to buy
in Sidney done up in tins air tight
about the size of a tin pint. After a
tin is opened it wont keep more than
two days. It is already cooked so that
we have only to warm it. We buy a
great deal of it, indeed it is the principal
part of our food. We also get fish pre
served the same way in small tins.
Then to-day for dinner we had yams
some days we have taro. The natives
cook our yams for us the same way
that they do their own – it would not be
nice boiled, it would be soft.
They roast them. If it is a small [xx]

they lay it on the fire and keep turn
ing it until it is roasted, just as you
would roast a potato. Some of our
yams are very little bigger than a
potato, but the small ones are de
licious, much niver than the large ones.
When it is roasted they scrape the
burnt skin off and then it is ready
to eat. But I never saw them cook
taro in this way nor large yams.
When they make their fire they have
a number of round stones which they
put on the top of the fire, and then
the stones are very hot – they put the
taro or yams on top of the stones and
cover them over with a great quantity
of leaves – and the leaves keep the heat
from escaping. By the time that
the stones are hot the wood is about
consumed, but they don't put on
any more wood, there is heat enough
in the stones themselves – Our girls take

turn about at cooking our yams.
We have porridge for breakfast. We get beau
tiful oatmeal from Sidney in small
tins. It would not do to get a larger
quantity at once for it dont keep long
We have plenty of milk. Mr Morrison
let a cow here. I suppose you would
like to see dear little [pepaxx]. She dont
walk alone yet, but she runs along the
wall or any place she can put her hand
against. She talks away at a great rate
and scolds too, but we dont know what
she is saying. She didn't know me when
I came home from the meeting, you
may be sure I was not well pleased
at her for forgetting me – Dear Ca[xx]
I hope you are a good girl– and that
you are seeking to followJesus. You
remember dear [pepin] had not much
time to think of death.
I remain
Your loving [brother]
John
